author: By Emily Cochrane
title: As Trump Seizes Wall Money, Congress’s Spending Power Weakens
description: The administration’s plan to divert more military funds to building a border wall is the latest example of the long-running erosion of Congress’s power of the purse.
content: WASHINGTON — When the Pentagon announced this month that it would divert billions more dollars in military funding to the construction of President Trump’s border wall, bipartisan outrage ricocheted across Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Inside the Bodega: Snacks, Smokes and Viral Fame
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 22, 2020.
content: “Everyone needs a bodega in their life.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Salvatore Ferragamo: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Maggie Astor
title: Loathing in Las Vegas: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: The Democratic candidates ripped into one another — and especially Michael Bloomberg — as the Nevada caucuses approached.
content: We are still not done counting votes in Iowa, but on we go anyway: It’s time for more caucuses. Let’s hope they go more smoothly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Randle
title: Inside the New York City Bodegas Going Viral on TikTok
description: Captured on video, the unique culture of the colorful corner stores is winning fans around the world.
content: The short video clip is filmed from behind a store counter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Tilney Burke
title: Can the Military Fix Base Housing?
description: Privatization has ushered in mold, mismanagement and worse.
content: Living on a military base can be idyllic. Children bike and run freely, cars drive slowly through the neighborhoods, parents keep an eye on one another’s kids, uniformed service members pop home for lunch, and everybody knows your name. In recent years however, these Mayberrys have been plagued by substantial unresolved maintenance issues, which many military renters chalk up to abject negligence from private military housing companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisha Cooper
title: The Winter Surfers of Rockaway Beach
description: On an icy break at the end of a subway line in Queens, freezing waves don’t deter the die-hards. For the hardiest, a wet suit is optional.
content: First light. Two figures stand on the boardwalk and scan the break. They look over a beach bleached of color, past wind-tattered WARNING flags, out to where waves are shattering against rock jetties. Then the two pick up their boards and shuffle across the snow and the sand and into the water, in a hurry to join the line of surfers bobbing offshore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Warren Buffett Praises Performance, but Offers No Surprises in Annual Letter
description: The Berkshire Hathaway chief noted the steady money making of the conglomerate, but gave no insight into succession or other hot topics.
content: At Berkshire Hathaway, 2019 was another good year — and an opportunity for its leader, Warren Buffett, to prepare his company for life without him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Latest Updates: Nevada Caucus
description: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
content: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Allentuck
title: Back on the Field, Yoenis Cespedes Is Mum About What Kept Him Away
description: The Mets hope the two-time All-Star outfielder, sidelined by injuries since 2018, can return to form.
content: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets outfielder Yoenis Cespedes is back with his team for the first time in 19 months, but he has yet to publicly discuss the series of  injuries that kept him away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Allentuck
title: Back on the Field, Yoenis Cespedes Is Mum About What Kept Him Away
description: The Mets hope the two-time All-Star outfielder, sidelined by injuries since 2018, can return to form.
content: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets outfielder Yoenis Cespedes is back with his team for the first time in 19 months, but he has yet to publicly discuss the series of  injuries that kept him away.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Warren Buffett Praises Performance, but Offers No Surprises in Annual Letter
description: The Berkshire Hathaway chief noted the steady money making of the conglomerate, but gave no insight into succession or other hot topics.
content: At Berkshire Hathaway, 2019 was another good year — and an opportunity for its leader, Warren Buffett, to prepare his company for life without him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: New Bid to Legalize Abortion in Argentina, With President’s Backing
description: Activists came close in 2018. This year, President Alberto Fernández is on their side and is expected to present a legalization bill to Congress.
content: BUENOS AIRES — Abortion rights activists in Argentina have formally started the second round in their effort to advance reproductive rights in the land of Pope Francis, buoyed by the hope that the country’s transformed political landscape will put their goal within reach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Jes Aznar
title: Adapting to Rising Seas, Schools Move to the Rafters and Cats Swim
description: On an island in the Philippines, waterlogged for one-third of every year, residents adjust to their sodden existence instead of fleeing.
content: BATASAN, Philippines — When the floods invade her home at night — and they always do, a little higher each year — Pelagia Villarmia curls up on her bed and waits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Same Goal, Different Playbook: Why Russia Would Support Trump and Sanders
description: Vladimir Putin is eager both to take the sheen off U.S. democracy and for a counterpart who is less likely to challenge his territorial and nuclear ambitions.
content: At first glance, it may seem contradictory that the nation’s intelligence agencies were telling Congress that President Vladimir V. Putin is presumably striving to get President Trump re-elected, while also warning Senator Bernie Sanders of evidence that he is the Russian president’s favorite Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 22, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 22, 2020.
content: An article on Thursday about Pete Buttigieg’s struggle to attract voters of color described incorrectly the votes cast in the 2016 Democratic caucuses in Elko County. There were 88 county delegates selected in the county, not 88 total votes recorded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Overlooked No More: Valaida Snow, Charismatic ‘Queen of the Trumpet’
description: She was not just a master musician, singer and dancer; she was also a teller of tall tales whose interviews could be as much a performance as her stage act.
content: Since 1851, many remarkable black men and women did not receive obituaries in The New York Times. This month, with Overlooked, we’re adding their stories to our archives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Étienne Lajoie and Salim Valji
title: In Canada, the Cost of Youth Hockey Benches the Next Generation
description: Colorado Avalanche defenseman Samuel Girard was a teenager when his parents sat him and his older brother Jérémy down in their Roberval, Quebec, home for an uncomfortable conversation that would dramatically alter their lives.
content: Colorado Avalanche defenseman Samuel Girard was a teenager when his parents sat him and his older brother Jérémy down in their Roberval, Quebec, home for an uncomfortable conversation that would dramatically alter their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: To This Group, Labor Is More Than a ‘White Man Who Works in a Factory’
description: The National Domestic Workers Alliance is putting nannies, housekeepers and home care workers at the center of the labor and progressive political movement.
content: LAS VEGAS — The three women knocking on doors around Las Vegas on Tuesday afternoon wanted to talk to people about the importance of voting, especially in a state with low voter turnout. They gave all the logistical details — where to go, what time to get there — and explained how early voting worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Democrats Are in Trouble
description: The party’s riskiest bet is now its likeliest.
content: I’ve been enthusiastic about Mike Bloomberg’s race for president from its inception, partly on the theory that he was best positioned to rescue and represent the Democratic Party’s moderate wing. After Wednesday night’s debate debacle in Las Vegas, I’m starting to fear his candidacy might inadvertently destroy that wing — while wrecking the party’s chances in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Overlooked No More: Valaida Snow, Charismatic ‘Queen of the Trumpet’
description: She was not just a master musician, singer and dancer; she was also a teller of tall tales whose interviews could be as much a performance as her stage act.

title: The Democrats Are in Trouble
description: The party’s riskiest bet is now its likeliest.
content: I’ve been enthusiastic about Mike Bloomberg’s race for president from its inception, partly on the theory that he was best positioned to rescue and represent the Democratic Party’s moderate wing. After Wednesday night’s debate debacle in Las Vegas, I’m starting to fear his candidacy might inadvertently destroy that wing — while wrecking the party’s chances in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Are You a Guilty Feminist?
description: Comedian Deborah Frances-White discusses the perfectly funny side of oh-so-imperfect feminism.
content: — Deborah Frances-White, comedian and host of “The Guilty Feminist” podcast
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: José Zalaquett, Leader in Chile’s Search for Truth, Dies at 77
description: He incurred the wrath of the dictator Augusto Pinochet, was exiled, and became an expert in how to heal traumatized countries.
content: José Zalaquett, a Chilean lawyer who investigated human rights abuses during Augusto Pinochet’s regime — spending time in prison and in exile as a result — and then helped bring to light similar abuses elsewhere in the Americas as well as in Africa and the Middle East, died on Feb. 15 in Santiago, Chile’s capital. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: ‘He Turned Purple’: U.S. Overlooks Ill Asylum Seekers
description: When the Trump administration rolled out its policy to force asylum seekers to wait in Mexico, officials said medical exemptions would help the sick. They haven’t.
content: MATAMOROS, Mexico — Maria Sam had lost count of her 9-year-old son’s seizures in the nearly three months since they applied for asylum in the United States but were told to wait on the Mexican side of the Rio Grande.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Infection Numbers Spike in South Korea, and Fear Builds
description: In total, 28 countries outside of China have reported more than 1,500 coronavirus cases.
content: [This briefing has ended. Read the latest updates on the coronavirus epidemic here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon and Farah Stockman
title: ‘All Hands on Deck’: Health Workers Race to Track Thousands of Americans Amid Coronavirus
description: Local health departments around the United States are scrambling to monitor thousands of people returning from travel in China and elsewhere. Among the tasks: daily calls, emails, texts.
content: After a long journey at sea on the Westerdam cruise ship, which was denied entry at ports across Asia over fears of the coronavirus, Holley Rauen finally returned home to Florida on Wednesday night. Moments later, she discovered that she had joined a cast of thousands who are being meticulously tracked by local health officials across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: A Polish Olympian Aimed to Join Team U.S.A. Things Got Ugly.
description: Aleksandra Shelton, a four-time Olympic fencer, grew frustrated by what she considered age and gender discrimination. But when she sought to compete for the United States, Polish officials stood in her way.
content: As an 11-year-old in Poland, Aleksandra Shelton saw her mother competing in a fencing competition on television. Intrigued by the sport and the allure of also appearing on TV someday, she built a saber fencing career that far surpassed her mother’s aspirations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: ‘We’re in a Petri Dish’: How a Coronavirus Ravaged a Cruise Ship
description: More than three days passed before Japan imposed a quarantine. That delay and other missteps helped produce the largest outbreak of the virus beyond China.
content: YOKOHAMA, Japan — The captain came over the intercom early in the evening: A passenger who had left the ship nine days earlier had tested positive for the new coronavirus sweeping through China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walter Thompson-Hernández and Ryan Young
title: In L.A., Kobe Dominates the Paint
description: In a city where street life happens largely in cars, residents speak of their loss through art and graffiti in public places.
content: Kobe Bryant and his daughter Gianna are gone but not forgotten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Expression of One at Sea, Perhaps
description: Trenton Charlson’s back, at his zenith, with a quality puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — When you’ve got a lot of entries with wings, as well as a ton of “rare” scrabbly letters and wild letter combinations flying around, you’ve got a Trenton Charlson puzzle. Both of those elements are so fanciful, and they’re so gracefully incorporated into this grid, that even if your solving experience is challenging, it’s full of zing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Deal With My Obnoxious Neighbors?
description: When cantankerous neighbors make life miserable, it can veer into harassment. There are ways to defend yourself.
content: Q: Two years ago I bought an apartment in a lovely co-op in Gramercy Park. As I soon discovered, I live on what some of my neighbors call “the complainer floor,” where a board member and her persnickety roommate complain about everything. Forget to properly clean a peanut jar before putting it in the recycling bin? Expect a letter from the managing agent. Any box not completely broken down — letter. Dog barks at a delivery man — letter. This duo prowls the trash-compactor rooms on every floor and reports their findings to the management company, directing them to send letters. My neighbors and I are sick of it. What can we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: A Feminist Cookbook Meant to Inspire Fuels Outrage Instead
description: The authors of “Rage Baking” started a different conversation than they intended.
content: The last thing Kathy Gunst and Katherine Alford expected when they published their cookbook “Rage Baking” was that the rage would be directed at them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: Vine Made the Internet Fall in Love With Short Videos
description: Now that they’re everywhere, is it time for Vine to make a comeback? The founder of Byte hopes so.
content: Vine, the short-form video app introduced in 2012, died as it lived: confusing people who didn’t use it, even as evidence of its influence surrounded them. It turned everyday people into stars on other platforms and beyond. Its musical whims warped the music industry. It cultivated memes that might have been dismissed as inside jokes if not for their tendency to flourish outside the app.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Missoni: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Missoni: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Missoni: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: At Burnley, Bricks and Mortar Secure a Premier League Future
description: Burnley has invested the bulk of its Premier League riches in facilities instead of players, believing that approach is its best bet to avoid relegation. Not every club follows the same plan.
content: BURNLEY, England — They tell the old war stories quite often at Burnley nowadays, and with a certain amount of nostalgic glee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Johni Cerny Dies at 76; Helped the Famous Find Their Roots
description: Fascinated by family trees since childhood, she became, Henry Louis Gates Jr. said, “the proverbial dean of American genealogical research.”
content: Johni Cerny, the chief genealogist for the PBS series “Finding Your Roots,” who helped some 200 famous people — among them Oprah Winfrey, Quincy Jones, Senator Bernie Sanders and Speaker Nancy Pelosi — trace their ancestry, died on Wednesday in Lehi, Utah, near Salt Lake City. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: What ‘Medicare for All’ Means After a Six-Year Strike for Health Benefits
description: To understand how union members in Las Vegas are thinking about Bernie Sanders, it helps to remember a picket line in the 1990s.
content: LAS VEGAS — They each remember that moment, just after dawn on a September day in 1991, when they walked out of the Frontier Hotel and Casino. There was music and singing — “Solidarity forever,” went the song. That first day, the atmosphere was more like a celebration than a work protest. But the strike would go on to last six years, four months and 10 days — one of the longest labor disputes in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Syria’s Drawn-Out Agony
description: A cease-fire is needed as Assad, with Russian help, attacks the last desperate refugees.
content: The Syrian civil war has entered its end game and it is as gruesome and fraught as any stretch in the hellish nine-year struggle. As the Syrian troops of Bashar al-Assad, backed by Russia, move to clear the last rebel-held enclave in northwestern Syria, some 900,000 civilian refugees — more than half of them children — have been pushed against the Turkish border in the freezing cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: America’s Parasite
description: Frankly, Trump doesn’t give a damn.
content: WASHINGTON — It’s funny that Donald Trump doesn’t like a movie about con artists who invade an elegant house and wreak chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Florida’s Voting-Rights Fight Could Tip the 2020 Election
description: The state’s voters said 1.4 million ex-felons should be allowed to vote. It’s now up to the courts to protect their rights.
content: Some day, and possibly sooner than they think, Republican lawmakers will be forced to confront the reality that they cannot sustain a major American political party in the 21st century on a strict diet of voter suppression, discouragement and disenfranchisement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: How to Win the Democratic Nomination, and Why It Could Get Complicated
description: Bernie Sanders says winning a plurality of delegates is good enough for the nomination. His rivals say a majority is needed. What does that mean? And why are superdelegates coming up again?
content: The last question at Wednesday night’s Democratic debate covered much wonkier territory than the fiery exchanges that preceded it. But it exposed a rift over what could become an extremely relevant topic: how the party’s presidential nominee should be chosen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel and Davey Alba
title: Digital Edits, a Paid Army: Bloomberg Is ‘Destroying Norms’ on Social Media
description: His campaign is testing the boundaries of what platforms like Twitter and Facebook allow in politics. They’re having trouble coming up with an answer.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — In the first few months of his presidential campaign, Michael R. Bloomberg has been as aggressive on social media as President Trump was four years ago. But with a lot more money to spend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Thomas Kaplan
title: One Guaranteed Winner in the Democratic Primary: Plans to Tax the Rich
description: Every leading candidate for the 2020 Democratic nomination is proposing trillions of dollars of new taxes on wealthy Americans and businesses. The divide in the field is how high to go.
content: WASHINGTON — The Democratic primary race remains highly unpredictable as Nevada’s caucuses are held on Saturday, but there is one thing we already know for sure about the party’s next presidential nominee: She or he has big plans to tax the very rich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: In Case on Wealth Test for Green Cards, a Scathing Sotomayor Dissent
description: The vote was 5 to 4, with the Supreme Court’s conservatives in the majority.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday allowed the Trump administration to move forward with plans to deny green cards to immigrants who are thought to be likely to become “public charges” by making even occasional and minor use of public benefits like Medicaid, food stamps and housing vouchers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: A Mexican Oil Chief’s Hide-Out: Sea Views and 2 Golf Courses
description: Before he was arrested this month, the former head of Pemex lay low in one of the world’s most discreet and exclusive locations on Spain’s sunny southern coast.
content: BENAHAVÍS, Spain — Fugitives often hole up in remote locations. But when the fugitive is the powerful former chief of Mexico’s state oil company, not just any old hide-out will do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Katie Rogers
title: Trump Was Furious That Passengers With Coronavirus Were Brought Back to U.S.
description: Among the passengers from the Diamond Princess cruise ship who were flown back were 14 American citizens who tested positive for the virus. The move took Mr. Trump by surprise.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump was infuriated that 14 American citizens who had tested positive for coronavirus were permitted to return this week to the United States, said two senior administration officials. The decision had taken the president, a self-declared “germophobe,” by surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Google Reaches Document Protection Deal in Antitrust Fight
description: The company had asked a court for limits on consultants working with the attorney general of Texas, who is leading a multistate investigation.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Google reached an agreement with a group of state attorneys general on Thursday over how officials will handle information it provides during their antitrust investigation into the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Why Are African-American Families Leaving Chicago?
description: “It’s an American tragedy,” said a pastor whose congregants have been disappearing for years, heading to cities throughout the Midwest and the South.
content: It has been 10 years since Isabel Wilkerson’s award-winning “The Warmth of Other Suns”  told the epic story of the Great Migration, the decades in the 20th century during which six million black Southerners relocated from the rural South to the North, Midwest and West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: Great Running Spots Across America
description: If you’re like me, vacation planning also means “where am I going to run?” planning.
content: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura M. Holson
title: Knitters Chronicle Climate Change One Stitch at a Time
description: Volunteers use different colors of yarn to make “temperature scarves” that serve as fashionable records of a warming world.
content: In January 2017, days after President Trump moved into the White House, Justin Connelly was at his home in Anacortes, Wash., bemoaning the fate of scientists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Who’s Your ‘Train Daddy’? On Byford’s Last Day, N.Y. Leaves No Doubt
description: Cheers, selfies and bagpipers as Andy Byford departs as the leader of the city’s subway.
content: It looked more like a reception for royalty than a farewell party for a bureaucrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Premeditated Chance Encounter
description: After admiring each other from afar for weeks, Mackenzie Jacks and William Frantz, who lived in neighboring apartment buildings, finally got a chance to meet, thanks to a thrill-seeking stranger.
content: Mackenzie Leigh Jacks and William Lawrence Frantz could not help but notice each other every time they crossed paths in the shared parking lot that stood between their Detroit apartment buildings in September 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Bottega Veneta: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Bottega Veneta: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Google Reaches Document Protection Deal in Antitrust Fight
description: The company had asked a court for limits on consultants working with the attorney general of Texas, who is leading a multistate investigation.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Google reached an agreement with a group of state attorneys general on Thursday over how officials will handle information it provides during their antitrust investigation into the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: Whitmer Thomas and the N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards
description: Watch a raw comedy special on HBO, or tune into the 51st N.A.A.C.P. Awards on BET.
content: WHITMER THOMAS: THE GOLDEN ONE (2020) 10 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. The Los Angeles-based comedian, actor and musician Whitmer Thomas keeps audiences guessing with his unusual, deeply personal sets. Is it appropriate to laugh when he performs his goth-pop song “Partied to Death?” (“My mommy drank herself to death/and I know she tried her very best/But now I can’t party because my mommy partied to death.”) Such painful realizations are sprinkled throughout this new comedy special, filmed at the same Florida bar where Thomas’s mother used to perform with her band. Much of the special is on the lighter side, though. Thomas riffs on his childhood in Alabama and his time in an emo rock band, and performs songs from his upcoming debut record, “Songs From the Golden One.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Resolved
description: Sophia Maymudes turns up with family (father, David), and turns in a commendable construction.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — The constructor setup today is really sweet and unique, so I’m going to paraphrase Will Shortz’s print introduction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: South Sudan Leader Appoints Ex-Rebel Leader as His Deputy
description: The rebel leader Riek Machar was sworn in as President Salva Kiir’s vice president, after the two men agreed to form a coalition government that many observers hoped would last.
content: JUBA, South Sudan — South Sudan opened a new chapter in its fragile emergence from civil war Saturday as the opposition leader Riek Machar was sworn in as President Salva Kiir’s vice president, a day after the two men agreed to form a coalition government that many observers prayed would last this time around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura M. Holson
title: Knitters Chronicle Climate Change One Stitch at a Time
description: Volunteers use different colors of yarn to make “temperature scarves” that serve as fashionable records of a warming world.
content: In January 2017, days after President Trump moved into the White House, Justin Connelly was at his home in Anacortes, Wash., bemoaning the fate of scientists.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Bottega Veneta: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Bottega Veneta: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Student Contest Winners: Teenagers Look at the News
description: We selected seven of our favorites from among the 200-plus entries in this year’s student letter-writing competition.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Cripple the Intelligence Agencies? Not Smart
description: What happens when intelligence officials warn that Russia is meddling in American politics again? Donald Trump gets mad — at the intelligence officials.
content: President Trump is intensifying his efforts to undermine the nation’s intelligence agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Greyhound to Stop Allowing Border Patrol Agents on Its Buses Without Warrants
description: The bus company announced the policy change only days after a leaked memo revealed that agents could not board without consent.
content: Greyhound Lines will no longer allow Border Patrol agents to conduct immigration checks on its buses without warrants, the company announced on Friday — one week after a leaked government memo revealed that agents could not board buses without consent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
title: Digital Tax Fight Emerges as Global Economic Threat
description: European finance ministers, meeting at the G20 in Riyadh, are pushing the United States for a global tax deal as a year-end deadline looms.
content: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The world’s top economic leaders warned on Saturday that an international tax fight between the United States and Europe poses a new threat to the global economy if a resolution is not reached this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pankaj Mishra
title: Donald Trump Is Going to India to Find Himself
description: Under Prime Minister Narendra Modi, India is the American president’s spiritual home: an inferno of systemic cruelty.
content: “I love Hindu,” Donald Trump proclaimed during his presidential campaign in 2016. That adoration of India’s majority population, and America’s richest and most obviously pro-Trump minority, may have just gotten deeper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Even 14-Year-Olds Who Kill Are Not Adults
description: If the young teens accused in Tessa Majors’s murder are convicted, a 1978 law could deny them a chance at redemption.
content: Tessa Majors, an 18-year-old Barnard College freshman with green hair, loved music, especially punk rock, and singing with her band.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Trump Makes the American Health Care System Even Worse
description: China’s failures on the coronavirus are distracting us from the mess we have at home.
content: President Trump praises a “strong, sharp and powerfully focused” Chinese President Xi Jinping for his handling of the coronavirus outbreak. “President Xi strongly leads what will be a very successful operation,” Trump said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Bernie Sanders, the Teflon Candidate, Faces Sudden New Tests
description: The Vermont senator has long brushed off political vulnerabilities and evaded attacks from rivals. But the spotlight on his front-runner status and possible Russian interference could pose challenges.
content: In the early years, there was his commentary on gender relations featuring a rape fantasy, his support for the Sandinistas and his honeymoon in the Soviet Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
title: Digital Tax Fight Emerges as Global Economic Threat
description: European finance ministers, meeting at the G20 in Riyadh, are pushing the United States for a global tax deal as a year-end deadline looms.
content: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The world’s top economic leaders warned on Saturday that an international tax fight between the United States and Europe poses a new threat to the global economy if a resolution is not reached this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Lynn Cohen, Magda on ‘Sex and the City,’ Is Dead at 86
description: She had a long career onstage and on film and TV. But she found her greatest fame late in life, as a stern housekeeper on a hit HBO series.
content: Lynn Cohen, the veteran actress best known for her role as Magda on the hit HBO series “Sex and the City,” died on Feb. 14 at her home in Manhattan. She was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump’s Efforts to Remove the Disloyal Heightens Unease Across His Administration
description: As senior officials are shown the door, a new personnel chief orders a search for political appointees as well as career officials deemed insufficiently supportive of the president.
content: WASHINGTON — In some of the most critical corners of the Trump administration, officials show up for work now never entirely sure who will be there by the end of the evening — themselves included.
source.name: The New York Times
